Usage: Reset default spacing; remove padding/margin from elements that inherit unwanted spacing
Notes: Base unit is 4px; all spacing tokens must be multiples of 4 for pixel-perfect alignment on retina displays

Usage: Hairline spacing between tightly grouped inline elements such as icon + label pairs or badge clusters
Notes: 4px is the atomic unit; never use odd values like 3px or 5px as they break the grid rhythm

Usage: Inner padding for compact components (chips, tags, small buttons); tight list item gaps
Notes: Most common small spacing token; use for any element that needs breathing room without visual separation

Usage: Default component padding (cards, form fields, buttons); standard gap between sibling elements
Notes: The workhorse token; when in doubt about spacing use space-4 as the starting point and adjust

Usage: Section inner padding; spacing between logically grouped content blocks within a card or panel
Notes: Preferred for card body padding and form group spacing; creates clear visual grouping without excess whitespace

Usage: Spacing between distinct content sections within a page; modal body padding; sidebar padding
Notes: Marks visual separation between unrelated content groups; signals a shift in context to the reader

Usage: Vertical spacing between major page sections (hero to features, features to pricing)
Notes: Section-level breathing room; combine with headings to create clear page hierarchy and scannable structure

Usage: Page-level vertical padding (top/bottom of full-width sections); large hero section internal spacing
Notes: Use for dramatic visual separation; too large for component-level spacing but ideal for page rhythm

Usage: Hero section top/bottom padding; large feature showcase spacing; landing page section gaps
Notes: Reserve for landing pages and marketing layouts; dashboards and apps rarely need this much space

Usage: Maximum section spacing for landing pages; full-bleed hero areas; dramatic visual breathing room
Notes: The ceiling of the spacing scale; if you need more than 96px reconsider the layout rather than adding tokens

Usage: Tables, data grids, brutalist design elements, code blocks, hard-edged containers
Notes: Sharp corners signal precision and data density; use in dashboards and technical interfaces

Usage: Input fields, small buttons, dropdown menus, tooltips, inline code snippets
Notes: Barely perceptible softening; prevents the harshness of 0px without looking rounded

Usage: Cards, modals, dialogs, medium buttons, notification toasts, dropdown panels
Notes: The default radius for most components; balanced between sharp and playful

Usage: Feature cards, hero images, large panels, image containers, promotional banners
Notes: Noticeably rounded; conveys approachability and modern design; popular in SaaS landing pages

Usage: Large modal dialogs, bottom sheets, mobile cards, overlay panels, feature showcase cards
Notes: Strong rounding for emphasis; use sparingly to avoid a toy-like appearance in professional UIs

Usage: Avatars, status indicators, pill badges, toggle switches, circular icon buttons, tags
Notes: Forces a perfect circle on square elements or pill shape on rectangles; never use on cards or containers

Usage: Subtle lift for interactive elements at rest (buttons, chips, input fields); hover state for flat elements
Notes: Barely visible but perceptible; adds dimensionality without visual noise; the lightest useful shadow

Usage: Cards, raised panels, dropdowns, navigation bars, content containers, sticky headers
Notes: The default shadow for most elevated components; two-layer shadow creates realistic depth perception

Usage: Dropdown menus, popovers, floating action buttons, hover states for cards, expanded panels
Notes: Use for elements that float above the page surface; signals interactivity and temporary elevation

Usage: Modals, dialog overlays, full-screen menus, notification panels, toast stacks
Notes: High-elevation shadow for overlays that require clear separation from the page beneath

Usage: Top-level toasts, command palettes, critical alerts, maximum elevation overlays
Notes: The strongest shadow; reserve for the single highest-priority overlay in the stacking context

Usage: Pressed button states, input fields (inset look), toggle switch tracks, well containers
Notes: Creates the illusion of a recessed surface; use for active/pressed states or container wells

Usage: Brand-colored glow beneath primary CTAs, promotional cards, featured elements, hover emphasis
Notes: Multiply the brand color at 20-30% opacity; never use on more than one element per viewport to avoid visual clutter

Scale: Mirrors light-mode scale with higher opacity
Usage: All elevated components in dark mode; cards, modals, dropdowns in dark theme
Notes: In dark mode increase shadow opacity to 2-3x because dark backgrounds absorb shadow; consider adding a subtle bright border instead

Keywords: tiny fine small print legal caption
Usage: Legal disclaimers, helper text, timestamps, badge labels, footnotes, captions
Notes: Minimum readable size; never go below 12px for body text; ensure 4.5:1 contrast ratio at this size

Usage: Secondary body text, table cell content, sidebar navigation, form labels, metadata
Notes: Common in dense UIs like dashboards; pair with font-weight 500 for better readability at small size

Usage: Primary body text, form inputs, button labels, list items, paragraph content
Notes: The foundation of all typography; browser default; optimal for long-form reading on screens

Usage: Lead paragraphs, card titles, nav links, prominent labels, subtitle text
Notes: Slightly larger than body for emphasis without heading-level weight; good for card headers

Usage: Section headings (h2), card group titles, modal headers, feature section titles
Notes: Primary section heading size; pair with font-weight 700 and letter-spacing -0.025em for impact

Usage: Page titles (h1), hero headlines, landing page main heading, feature hero text
Notes: Display-level heading; use clamp() for responsive sizing: clamp(1.875rem, 4vw, 2.25rem)

Usage: Headings (h1-h3), display text, hero headlines, large bold text, banner titles
Notes: Tighter leading prevents headings from looking sparse; never use on body text or paragraphs

Usage: Body paragraphs, form fields, list items, descriptions, any multi-line readable text
Notes: The gold standard for body text readability; provides adequate space for ascenders and descenders

Usage: Primary CTAs, active navigation, links, selected states, primary buttons, brand accents
Notes: Must pass WCAG AA contrast (4.5:1) against white backgrounds; test both light and dark mode

Usage: Secondary buttons, metadata text, supporting UI elements, breadcrumbs, inactive tabs
Notes: Lower visual priority than primary; use for actions that are available but not the main path

Usage: Feature highlights, promotional badges, new-feature indicators, accent borders, special states
Notes: Use sparingly (max 10% of UI surface) to maintain visual impact; too much accent dilutes emphasis

Usage: Success toasts, valid form states, completed steps, positive metrics, approval indicators
Notes: Never use green alone to convey meaning; always pair with an icon or text for color-blind accessibility

Usage: Warning banners, approaching-limit indicators, unsaved-changes notices, caution states
Notes: Amber provides urgency without alarm; pair with a warning icon (triangle exclamation) for clarity

Usage: Error messages, invalid form fields, destructive action buttons, failed states, delete confirmations
Notes: Always pair with descriptive text; never rely solely on color; add aria-invalid for form fields

Usage: Page backgrounds, card surfaces, modal backgrounds, sidebar backgrounds, panel surfaces
Notes: Foundation layer; all other colors must have sufficient contrast against the surface color in both themes

Usage: Card borders, input outlines, dividers, table cell borders, separator lines, section dividers
Notes: Subtle enough to define boundaries without competing with content; increase opacity on focus states

Usage: Normal document flow content; page body, main content area, standard positioned elements
Notes: The default stacking layer; avoid setting z-index unless an element genuinely needs to overlap another

Usage: Dropdown menus, select menus, autocomplete lists, popover panels, date pickers
Notes: Must sit above page content but below sticky headers; always pair with click-outside dismiss behavior

Usage: Sticky navigation bars, fixed headers, floating toolbars, sticky table headers, persistent banners
Notes: Above dropdowns so sticky nav remains visible when a dropdown opens elsewhere on the page

Usage: Modal dialogs, full-screen overlays, bottom sheets, lightbox containers, confirmation dialogs
Notes: Always render a backdrop at z-29 to trap focus and prevent interaction with content beneath

Usage: Toast notifications, snackbar messages, floating alerts, system-level banners, progress indicators
Notes: Must float above modals so toasts remain visible even when a modal is open; auto-dismiss in 3-5s

Usage: Tooltips, contextual hints, cursor-following popovers, drag-and-drop ghosts, max-elevation UI
Notes: The ceiling of the z-index scale; nothing should ever need higher; if it does restructure stacking contexts

Usage: Hover color changes, opacity toggles, checkbox/radio state changes, focus ring appearance
Notes: Imperceptible as animation but prevents jarring instant changes; use for micro-state transitions

Usage: Button hover/active states, dropdown open/close, accordion expand, tab switching, fade in/out
Notes: The default transition speed for most UI interactions; feels responsive without being abrupt

Usage: Modal open/close, sidebar slide, page transitions, skeleton-to-content reveal, large panel animations
Notes: For larger elements that need graceful movement; anything above 300ms risks feeling sluggish

Usage: Elements entering the viewport (dropdowns opening, modals appearing, toasts sliding in)
Notes: Objects entering the screen should decelerate to a stop; mimics natural physics of arriving objects

Usage: Expanding/collapsing accordions, toggle switches, tab content transitions, size changes
Notes: Symmetric acceleration and deceleration; the safest default easing when unsure which curve to use

Usage: Error messages, validation, destructive actions, alert borders, error badges
Notes: Semantic token — maps to red-500 by default but can be themed. Always pair with error text.

Usage: Success messages, confirmation, positive status, completed states, valid input
Notes: Semantic token — maps to green-500 by default. Use with aria-live for announcements.

Usage: Warning alerts, caution states, pending status, attention-required indicators
Notes: Semantic token — maps to amber-500. Ensure sufficient contrast on light backgrounds.

Usage: Information banners, tips, help messages, status indicators, feature callouts
Notes: Semantic token — maps to blue-500. Use for non-critical informational UI.

Usage: Button hover/active, toggle, checkbox, ripple, focus ring, tooltip show
Notes: Micro-interactions that should feel instant. Below 100ms feels simultaneous; 150ms feels snappy.

Usage: Dropdown open, popover show, card hover, accordion expand, tab switch, modal fade
Notes: Standard interaction timing. 200-300ms is the sweet spot for most UI transitions.

Usage: Page transitions, drawer slide, modal scale, sidebar collapse, view transitions, layout shift
Notes: For larger elements or emphasis. Above 500ms risks feeling sluggish.

Keywords: spring, bounce, elastic, natural, physics, organic
Usage: Playful interactions, success celebrations, attention-grabbing reveals, element entrance
Notes: CSS linear() approximation of spring physics. Use for organic feel. Falls back to ease-out.

Keywords: opacity, transparent, dim, muted, overlay, disabled
Usage: Disabled states (40), overlays (50-80), hover effects (10-20), muted text (60), watermarks (10)
Notes: Standardized opacity levels prevent inconsistent transparency. Disabled = 50, Overlay = 50-80.
